title: Mpox (Monkeypox) Vaccination: What to Know
author: Shishira Sreenivas

content: Mpox (formerly known as monkeypox) is a viral infection caused by the mpox virus. It’s a milder, less serious relative of the virus that causes smallpox . If you’ve been exposed to it, within 3 weeks you’ll notice flu -like symptoms along with a rash that might look like pimples or a blister.

There’s no specific treatment or cure for mpox. But studies show smallpox vaccines can provide some protection against mpox. The FDA has approved two smallpox vaccines, Jynneos and ACAM2000, that might help prevent mpox. The vaccine is most effective if you take it before or soon after exposure to the virus.
Here’s a quick guide on the mpox vaccination, who needs it, when to take it, and what you can expect.

content_blocks.text: Mpox (formerly known as monkeypox) is a viral infection caused by the mpox virus. It’s a milder, less serious relative of the virus that causes smallpox . If you’ve been exposed to it, within 3 weeks you’ll notice flu -like symptoms along with a rash that might look like pimples or a blister.

There’s no specific treatment or cure for mpox. But studies show smallpox vaccines can provide some protection against mpox. The FDA has approved two smallpox vaccines, Jynneos and ACAM2000, that might help prevent mpox. The vaccine is most effective if you take it before or soon after exposure to the virus.
Here’s a quick guide on the mpox vaccination, who needs it, when to take it, and what you can expect.

sections.heading: Mpox (Monkeypox) Vaccines: Jynneos and ACAM2000
content: Mpox can spread through close contact, often skin-to-skin, with an infected person or an animal. To control the current outbreak and slow the spread, the FDA has approved two vaccines:

Jynneos . Also called Imvamune or Imvanex, the vaccine contains a live vaccinia virus that’s designed to prevent infection for those who are at high risk for mpox. It’s a two-dose vaccine that you’ll take 4 weeks apart.

content_blocks.text: Mpox can spread through close contact, often skin-to-skin, with an infected person or an animal. To control the current outbreak and slow the spread, the FDA has approved two vaccines:

Jynneos . Also called Imvamune or Imvanex, the vaccine contains a live vaccinia virus that’s designed to prevent infection for those who are at high risk for mpox. It’s a two-dose vaccine that you’ll take 4 weeks apart.

content: The injection was originally given under the skin (subcutaneously). But in early August 2022, the FDA approved an emergency use authorization (EUA) that allows health care workers to give the vaccine between the layers of your skin (intradermally) if you’re 18 or older and at high risk for mpox infection.
This EUA also allows people under age 18 who are at high risk for this infection to get the Jynneos vaccine. But they must get it subcutaneously, not intradermally.
An EUA is not the same as or as thorough as an FDA approval. But with it, the FDA is able to speed up the availability of vaccines during a health care emergency.

As mpox spreads, experts have found the current vaccine supply can’t keep up. Intradermal use of the vaccine allows less of it to be used in each injection. This means there are more doses available and more people can get vaccinated.

An EUA is not the same as or as thorough as an FDA approval. But with it, the FDA is able to speed up the availability of vaccines during a health care emergency.

As mpox spreads, experts have found the current vaccine supply can’t keep up. Intradermal use of the vaccine allows less of it to be used in each injection. This means there are more doses available and more people can get vaccinated.

content: When given through the intradermal method, there may be more redness, firmness, itchiness, and swelling at the injection site, the FDA said. They added these side effects were manageable and not severe.
This takes about 14 days after the second dose for your body to build a strong immune response to the virus.

If you’ve had the smallpox vaccine in the past, you might only need one dose. Jynneos is safe to use if you have HIV. It’s also safe if you have eczema or other skin conditions, or of you have any other conditions that weaken your immune system .

ACAM2000. Originally used against the smallpox virus, this vaccine contains a live virus that can multiply. It’s given as a prick on your skin. The person giving you the vaccine will dip a two-pronged steel needle into the vaccine solution and poke a spot on your upper arm several times.

A small lesion or a red, itchy bump (called “a take”) may form at the injection site after 3-4 days, and the virus can grow from here. It usually takes about 6 weeks for the lesion to heal, and it may leave you with a small scar. Take care not to touch the lesion. After you get the vaccine, it takes about 4 weeks for your body to build an immune response to the virus.

sections.heading: Who Should Get the Mpox Vaccine?
content: The CDC recommends vaccines for people who have been exposed to mpox or those who are more likely to get it.
This includes:
bullets: If you’ve come in close contact with someone who has mpox
If you’ve had sex with someone in the past 2 weeks who has tested positive for mpox
You’ve had multiple sexual partners in the past 2 weeks in an area with a mpox outbreak
If you work in a lab and handle samples or animals with orthopoxvirus
Health care workers

Health care workers

sections.heading: When Can You Get the Vaccine?
content: While it’s best to get the vaccine before you're exposed to mpox, getting it afterward may still help prevent the disease or make the symptoms less serious. Experts call this prophylaxis.

sections.heading: When Can You Get the Vaccine?
content: While it’s best to get the vaccine before you're exposed to mpox, getting it afterward may still help prevent the disease or make the symptoms less serious. Experts call this prophylaxis.

content_blocks.text: While it’s best to get the vaccine before you're exposed to mpox, getting it afterward may still help prevent the disease or make the symptoms less serious. Experts call this prophylaxis.

content: Vaccine strategies for mpox include:

Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP). If you’ve been exposed to mpox, the CDC recommends getting a vaccine within 4 days from the date of exposure for the best results. This will prevent the virus from multiplying.

content_blocks.text: Vaccine strategies for mpox include:

Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP). If you’ve been exposed to mpox, the CDC recommends getting a vaccine within 4 days from the date of exposure for the best results. This will prevent the virus from multiplying.

content: You can get the vaccine between 4-14 days after exposure before symptoms develop. But it won’t be as effective. It may reduce the serious symptoms, and it might be able to prevent an infection. In some cases, you could get it after 14 days, especially if you’re more likely to get a severe infection and your immune system isn’t as strong due to other illnesses.
But studies show that if you start to have symptoms, a vaccine may not protect you.

Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP)++ after an outbreak. If you have certain risk factors that make you more likely to get mpox, you may get this vaccine even if you’ve not been around someone who has tested positive.
Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP). This vaccine strategy is used for those who are at high risk for exposure. This can include lab, health care, and public health workers.

content_blocks.text: You can get the vaccine between 4-14 days after exposure before symptoms develop. But it won’t be as effective. It may reduce the serious symptoms, and it might be able to prevent an infection. In some cases, you could get it after 14 days, especially if you’re more likely to get a severe infection and your immune system isn’t as strong due to other illnesses.
But studies show that if you start to have symptoms, a vaccine may not protect you.

Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP)++ after an outbreak. If you have certain risk factors that make you more likely to get mpox, you may get this vaccine even if you’ve not been around someone who has tested positive.
Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP). This vaccine strategy is used for those who are at high risk for exposure. This can include lab, health care, and public health workers.

sections.heading: Where Can You Get Mpox Vaccines?
content: In the U.S., both vaccines can be found at the Strategic National Stockpile (SNS). It’s a network of locations within the country and contains a vast stock of medical supplies like antidotes and vaccines. They’re in charge of supplying your local public health agencies with supplies if there’s a national medical emergency or during an outbreak.

content_blocks.text: In the U.S., both vaccines can be found at the Strategic National Stockpile (SNS). It’s a network of locations within the country and contains a vast stock of medical supplies like antidotes and vaccines. They’re in charge of supplying your local public health agencies with supplies if there’s a national medical emergency or during an outbreak.

content: The U.S. has a limited supply of mpox vaccines. If you’re at risk for mpox or if you’ve been exposed to someone who tested positive, tell your doctor. They can give you a vaccine if you’re eligible for one.
If you’re under 18, your doctor will have to consult with the CDC before they can give you a vaccine.

sections.heading: Does the Mpox Vaccine Cause Side Effects?
content: Both vaccines can cause reactions where the needle enters your skin, such as:
If you got Jynneos, side effects can also include fever, headaches, and muscle pain.
If you got ACAM200, side effects could include:
If you notice these side effects after you leave the clinic, let your doctor know immediately.
bullets: Pain
Swelling
Redness
Itching
Fever
Rash
Lymph node swelling
Myocarditis (swelling of the heart muscle)
Pericarditis (swelling of the sac-like tissue around the heart)

content_blocks.text: Both vaccines can cause reactions where the needle enters your skin, such as:
associated_bullets: Pain
Swelling
Redness
Itching

content_blocks.text: If you got Jynneos, side effects can also include fever, headaches, and muscle pain.
If you got ACAM200, side effects could include:
associated_bullets: Fever
Rash
Lymph node swelling
Myocarditis (swelling of the heart muscle)
Pericarditis (swelling of the sac-like tissue around the heart)

content_blocks.text: If you notice these side effects after you leave the clinic, let your doctor know immediately.

sections.heading: Who Shouldn’t Get The Mpox Vaccine?
content: The mpox vaccine isn’t suitable for everyone.

content_blocks.text: The mpox vaccine isn’t suitable for everyone.

content: Avoid ACAM2000:
You should take precautions before you get Jynneos if you:

After you get the vaccine, it’s best to wait for 30 minutes to see if you have any reaction to it. If you have an allergic reaction, tell your doctor about it. If it’s a medical emergency, call 911 or go to the nearest hospital.
bullets: For infants less than 12 months of age
If you had congenital conditions (at birth)
If you have a weakened immune system from conditions like HIV or AIDS
If you have eczema or other skin conditions that cause you to shed the top layers of your skin fast
If you are pregnant
If you have heart disease
If you use topical steroid medication for eye disease
Have had a severe allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to chicken or egg protein
Have had Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS). It’s a rare, serious skin condition.
Have had toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). It’s a deadly condition that causes skin to peel and cause blisters. It’s usually caused by a drug reaction.

If you are pregnant
If you have heart disease
If you use topical steroid medication for eye disease

Have had toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). It’s a deadly condition that causes skin to peel and cause blisters. It’s usually caused by a drug reaction.

WHO: “Multi-country monkeypox outbreak in non-endemic countries.”

FDA: “ACAM2000 (Smallpox Vaccine) Questions and Answers,” “Monkeypox Update: FDA Authorizes Emergency Use of JYNNEOS Vaccine to Increase Vaccine Supply,” “Fact Sheet For Healthcare Providers Administering Vaccine: Emergency Use Authorization Of Jynneos (Smallpox And Monkeypox Vaccine, Live, Non-Replicating) For Prevention Of Monkeypox Disease In Individuals Determined To Be At High Risk For Monkeypox Infection.”
U.S. Department of Human and Health Services: “Strategic National Stockpile (SNS).”
Yale Medicine: “Emergency Use Authorization Vs. Full FDA Approval: What’s the Difference?”
meta_description: Mpox (monkeypox) spreads if you come in close contact to an infected person or animal. To control the outbreak, the FDA has approved two vaccines. Here’s a guide on mpox vaccine, who needs it, how to get it, what to expect.
